blog.title: Spring comes to Winterfell
blog.description: My personal collection of GoT/ ASoIaF

summary: The homecoming journeys (P3.2): The Stark kids
title: The homecoming journeys (P3.2): The Stark kids
body:
Part 1: Theon & Jorah

Part 2: Jaime & Tyrion

Part 3.1: Robb- the lone wolf

In the previous part, we have discussed how Robb lost Winterfell and the North when he drove South for the war and how his choice of Vengeance over Home led him to his own demise. His decision to attack Casterly Rock instead of  reclaiming the North was the final nail in the coffin. Robb’s last war plan, which was a divergence from the books, was a conscious choice from the show writers to emphasize how Robb’s choice was different from that of his siblings. And I believe the consequences would be different. Robb chose the path of a lonewolf and he died. The surviving Stark kids would not repeat the mistakes of their brother. They would choose Home (and each other) over everything else. The strength of the pack will help them survive the Long Night and the threats from other enemies.

Throughout the length of the series, the kids were driven away from home, separated, constantly endangered, abused and even murdered. 

Each of them suffered traumatic experiences, witnessing their loved ones die horribly before their very eyes. However, despite being forced to abandon their identity, they never stopped thinking of home and their family. Winterfell (and the North) holds a sacred place in their heart, the place of childhood memory, love and hope. No other characters in the series have memories of home as vivid as the Starklings. Home is where they drew their strengths from.

“Winterfell is our home. It’s ours, and Arya’s, and Bran’s and Rickon’s, wherever they are. It belongs to our family. We have to fight for it.” (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

Home is the place where their paths finally converge. It was a promise from the beginning.

“Different roads sometimes lead to the same castle.” 

(Jon to Arya, Jon II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  makebeliever

Coming home to know who they are and who to fight for

In this part, we will have a brief look on the homecoming journeys of the Starklings and elaborate how their arcs mean for their future development and the restoration of House Stark. I will quote some texts from the books (which have been adapted on screen or do not contradict with what introduced to us about the characters by the show) to have a better of understanding about the inner thoughts and motivations of the characters.

Bran

“Winterfell had been the only home he had ever known.” (Bran II, A Game of Thrones)

Among the Starklings, perhaps Bran is the most knowledgeable of the castle’s architecture and its stories, and the topography of  the surrounding area. He is the one who knows every little corner of Winterfell, even the most secretive part of it. As the younger son, Bran didn’t expect to inherit the ancestral home. His role is to become Robb’s bannerman. But he had his own way to become lord of the castle. As he frequently climbed to Winterfell’s rooftop, where he claimed his “second home”, he saw the life of the castle, everyone, and everything.

Bran could perch for hours among the shapeless, rain-worn gargoyles that brooded over the First Keep, watching it all: the men drilling with wood and steel in the yard, the cooks tending their vegetables in the glass garden, restless dogs running back and forth in the kennels, the silence of the godswood, the girls gossiping beside the washing well. It made him feel like he was the lord of the castle, in a way even Robb would never know. (Bran II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

Even the crypts do not frighten Bran. He feels like he is a part of it.

Their footsteps echoed through the cavernous crypts. The shadows behind them swallowed his father as the shadows ahead retreated to unveil other statues; no mere lords, these, but the old Kings in the North. On their brows they wore stone crowns. […] Their faces were stern and strong, and some of them had done terrible things, but they were Starks everyone, and Bran knew all their tales. He had never feared the crypts; they were part of his home and who he was, and he had always known that one day he would lie here too. (Bran VII, A Clash of Kings)

Bran’s happy childhood didn’t last long. His life changed upside down after he was shoved from the tower by Jaime and lost his mobility. However, the worst was yet to come. Waking up from his coma, Bran was disappointed that his mother had left him, although she left to investigate the cause of his fall and to demand justice for him. Maester Luwin was surprised and couldn’t answer the seemingly childlike question from Bran.

Luwin: Your mother had to leave Winterfell to protect the family.

Bran: How can she protect the family if she’s not with her family?

What happened after proved that Bran was actually reasonable. One cannot protect the family while he/she is not with the family. Robb left for war and Bran was assumed Lord of Winterfell in his stead. That was a huge responsibility for a cripple 10-year-old child. With the help from Maester Luwin, Bran took care of Winterfell and its people, showing great potentials to become a good lord. 

Still, defending the whole North and Winterfell while the best Northern soldiers were going South with Robb was too much of a responsibility for a child. Winterfell was sacked after a surprise attack from ironbonn led by Theon. Bran experienced the first horrors in his life seeing Ser Rodrick beheaded, his house burnt and Master Luwin killed. 

In his last words, Maester Luwin reminded Bran that there was still hope under the ruins, as long as he lived.

Bran: They burnt everything. 

Luwin: Not everything. Not you. (2x10)

The castle gave Bran strength to carry on. As he fled North, he turned to have a last look of “the castle that had been his life”.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought, I’m not dead either. (Bran VII, A Clash of Kings)

Following the call from the Bloodraven, Bran and his companion arrived in a cave under a heart tree beyond the Wall. While he was training in the cave, Bran was frequently brought back to Winterfell in the visions and he didn’t want to leave. Because staying in the visions was the only way he could be home.

When Bloodraven warned him if he stayed in the visions for too long, he will be drowned, he responded with despair.

I wasn’t drowning. I was Home. (Bran to Bloodraven, 6x02)

Bran has been through a horrific journey. Be crippled by a knight he aspired to become when he grows up, betrayed and captured by a surrogate brother, witnessed Ser Rodrick and Maester Luwin killed, saw his home burnt, captured and tortured by the mutineers, witnessed the death of his mentors and companions, hunted by the dead beyond the Wall, learned in a short time to master the magical power he can hardly control. Now he’s back home but it’s not yet safe. The Dead is marching on them, and he bears the responsibility to face the Night King and save his home and humankind. As a child, Bran always dreamed to become a knight and was so devastated when he learned he could never walk again, meaning there was no chance to fulfilling his dream. But he might in the end be a knight in another way. 

Benjen to Bran: You must learn to control it before the Night King comes. One way or another, he will find his way to the world of men. And when he does, you will be there waiting for him. And you will be ready. (6x06)

Bran to Sansa: I need to learn to see better. When the Long Night comes again, I need to be ready. (7x03)

Bran’s journey home is for him to gain knowledge and wisdom about history and learn to apply such insights for the benefit of mankind. In season 7, Bran lost his sense of self. He claims to be the 3-Eyed-Raven now and only remembers how it was to be Bran Stark. Does he forget that he is Bran? Does he forget he is a Stark? For someone who knows and loves every inch of Winterfell, who knows all the story of the Starks before him, who endured so much pain and horror to be back home and defend it, just to lose himself and become emotionless would render the story totally bitter and quite meaningless.

It’s not like he’s not Bran anymore. It’s just the part of his head that is Bran is a much, much smaller part of his personality now. When he is with the Starks and his family, that part of him flares up. But really, he’s transcended that – he kind of exists beyond human beings and human issues and problems. He is time. (Isaac Hempstead Wright on Bran Stark in season 8) 

I’m very curious to see how Bran continues his journey. And if the speculation that the Night King was the ancestor of House Stark is true, perhaps in season 8, Bran would need to learn much more about his family’s history and secrets, and he would come to understand what it truly means to be a Stark of Winterfell. 

Arya

Arya left Winterfell for King’s Landing with Ned and Sansa since season 1 and ever since, her life has become a horror story.

After Ned was beheaded, Arya went into the hiding, travelled with the Night’s Watch’s recruits, became a captive at Harrenhal and then the Hound’s. Her hope of reuniting with her mother and her brother Robb was scattered when she finally arrived at the Red Wedding just in time to witness her family and the Stark soldiers being slaughtered and Robb’s headless body was mocked. 

Gif:  lovableamy

After wandering in the Riverlands and Eyrie with the Hound, Arya fled to Bravos to become an assassin. Revenge became her sole purpose in life. Citing the list of people she wanted to kill was her bedtime habit.

In order to become a Faceless Man, Arya was trained to give up who she was to become “no one”. However, at the back of her mind, Arya could never forget where she came from.

When you smell our candles burning, what does it make you think of, my child? Winterfell, she might have said. I smell Hodor laughing, and Jon and Robb battling in the yard, and Sansa singing about some stupid lady fair. I smell the crypts where the stone kings sit, I smell hot bread baking, I smell the godswood. I smell my wolf, I smell her fur, almost as if she were still beside me. (Arya II, A Feast for Crows)

As Jaqen requested, Arya had to give up her possession. She threw her old clothing and silver into the lagoon, but was unable to let go of Needle, the tiny piece of Home that still remained with her. She then chose to hide the sword under the rocks.

Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes. (Arya II, A Feast for Crows)

Even when Arya managed to defeat the Waif and was claimed by Jaqen to finally be “No one”, she refused and declared that she was always Arya Stark of Winterfell while pointing Needle at his chest.

A girl is Arya Stark of Winterfell. And I’m going Home. (Arya to Jaqen H’ghar, 6x08)

She then left the House of Black and White to come back to Westeros and continue her revenge mission by wiping out House Frey. 

Gif:  supercanaries

On her way to King’s Landing to finish her kill list (Cersei), Arya was informed that Jon had taken back Winterfell and became King in the North. She decided to abandon the mission and go home instead, prioritizing her family over vengeance. The moment Arya changed her direction and rode back to Winterfell was when she stopped being a lone wolf. She finally had a pack to join. 

Nymeria, it’s me. Arya. I’m heading North, girl. Back to Wintefell. I’m finally going Home. Come with me. (Arya to Nymeria, 7x02)

Arya’s homecoming journey revolves much around brutality, death, revenge and justice. The degree of ruthlessness and brutality she inflicted on her enemies is quite alarming. Luckily, the bright spot is, she never let hatred and rage took over her to the point that she would kill innocents. She refused to complete her assignment of killing Lady Crane (note that the actress actually played Cersei, her number one enemey), knowing fully well that the failed mission would risk her life. Later on, aware of the Frey women’s innocence in the Red Wedding, she didn’t let them drink the poisoned wine either.

Among the Stark kids, Arya has the highest risk of following Robb’s footsteps since revenge has become her primary motivation for a considerable period of time. And as far as we know, blind vengeance only leads to self-destruction. And I hope that would not be the path for Arya. Her childhood was ruined by all the misfortunes happened to her family, forcing her to become a cold-blooded assassin. Winterfell and all the good memories of her family were the only lights in Arya’s darkest days which prevent her from totally losing herself and the humanity that was left in her. Now she’s home with her siblings, would the love in her heart eventually outgrow the hatred that she embraced for years?

There’s this split with Arya between trying to be who she wants to be — getting back to back to that naiveté and innocence with her family — and her unfinished business. (Maisie Williams on Arya Stark in season 8, EW interview)

Another positive aspect of Arya’s journey that makes us hopeful is, while travelling across a war-torn Westeros, Arya lived among the common folks, befriended with them and suffered the same as they did, she comes to understand the ugliness of war, of the current oppressive social system and what the people really need. She develops a sense of empathy with the common people and is always ready to defend the weak. Her path also led her to an encounter with the Lannister soldiers when she realized the soldiers were just common folks dragged into someone else’s war. They are humans with all the concerns, and hopes and dreams, and families to care for, just like her. 

This is a parallel with Robb’s encounter with the Lannister child soldier who lost his leg in the Battle of Oxcross, allowing us to see wars from different view point. I believe with all her experiences living among the commoners, Arya will finally realize that wars and revenge would not be the solution for Westeros. Would that be interesting if the person who is driven by revenge is the one who learns to forgive and actively seek out a way to end war for the benefit of the common people? Would that be meaningful if the person who is trained to bring death, to serve the Many-Faced God will end up fighting to save lives?

Arya knows that she can never be as good a lady (aka a ruler) as Sansa and she still need to figure out what she can do.

I was never going to be as good as a lady as you. So I have to be something else. (Arya to Sansa, 7x07)

What does “something else” mean for Arya? A fighter, maybe. But she might also have a more important role to play in the political landscape of the North (and Westeros) afterwards.

Remember Robb’s conversation with Talisa about his father?

Gif:  iheartgot

He once told me that being a lord is like being a father, except you have thousands of children and you worry about all of them. The farmers plowing the fields are yours to protect. The charwomen scrubbing the floors, yours to protect. The soldiers you order into battle. (Robb to Talisa, 2x08)

Taking care of the common folks under their rule is a Stark tradition.

Since Arya is so much inspired by Ned, she will follow the example of her father when she comes back to Winterfell. 

Back at Winterfell, they had eaten in the Great Hall almost half the time. Her father used to say that a lord needed to eat with his men, if he hoped to keep them. “Know the men who follow you,” she heard him tell Robb once, “and let them know you. Don’t ask your men to die for a stranger.” At Winterfell, he always had an extra seat set at his own table, and everyday a different man would be asked to join him. […] Arya had loved nothing better than to sit at her father’s table and listen to them talk. (Arya II, A Game of Thrones) 

Sitting among the soldiers and commoners, talking with them, listening to their concerns and being the voice of the people, it’s not too far-fetch to picture Arya that way. The skills she learned as a Faceless Men trainee to play her part as someone else, “speak in their voices”, “live in their skin” could be transcended to serve people instead, if she could utilize such skills to empathize with people of various backgrounds. But first of all, let’s pray that she would find the strength to let go of vengeance and deploy her “expertise” for good. 

Sansa

Sansa began the series excited to leave home for King’s Landing to fulfill her dream of marrying a handsome young prince and becoming queen someday. Her dream soon turned into a nightmare when Ned was executed.

She was then used a pawn passed around by the powerful players in the game, including the Lannisters, the Tyrells, Littlefinger, the Boltons. She went through a series of mistreat and abuses both mentally and physically under several captors who murdered her family; and was forced into marriage for her claim of the North several times against her will. Sansa had little agency over her situation, she had to pretend to survive, but in her mind, she was free. She is still a Stark, through and through; and her heart belongs to Winterfell.

I’m a Stark. I’ll always be a Stark. (Sansa to Lyanna Mormont when questioned if she is a Bolton or a Lannister due to her (forced) marriages, 6x07)

The scene where Sansa built the snow castle in the Eyrie is a masterpiece, both in the book and the show.

The snow fell and the castle rose. Two walls ankle-high, the inner taller than the outer. Towers and turrets, keeps and stairs, a round kitchen, a square armory, the stables along the inside of the west wall. It was only a castle when she began, but before very long Sansa knew it was Winterfell. She found twigs and fallen branches beneath the snow and broke off the ends to make the trees for the godswood. For the gravestones in the lichyard she used bits of bark. Soon her gloves and her boots were crusty white, her hands were tingling, and her feet were soaked and cold, but she did not care. The castle was all that mattered. Some things were hard to remember, but most came back to her easily, as if she had been there only yesterday. The Library Tower, with the steep stonework stair twisting about its exterior. The gatehouse, two huge bulwarks, the arched gate between them, crenellations all along the top… (Sansa VII, A Storm of Swords)

It is amazing about the level of details that Sansa remembered about Winterfell and how she crafted it from the snow. Among the Starklings, perhaps Sansa and Bran are those who know so much details of the castle architecture, foreshadowing they will be the ones who rebuild the structure after the war.

Like her siblings, Sansa also drew her strengths from Winterfell in her darkest days.

She wondered where this courage had come from, to speak to him (Littlefinger) so frankly. From Winterfell, she thought. I am stronger within the walls of Winterfell. (Sansa VII, A Storm of Swords)

Even Ramsay’s abuse couldn’t break Sansa then. After her escape, Sansa was more determined than ever to take back her home from the Boltons.

There’s only one place we can go. Home. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

If we don’t take back the North, we’ll never be safe. I want you to help me, but I’ll do it myself if I have to. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

Sansa played a pivotal role in regaining Winterfell for the Starks. With her wits, she provoked Ramsay about the fragility of his position due to his bastard status, indirectly causing the death of Roose Bolton, thus eliminating the man who betrayed Robb.

Her strong determination motivated Jon to pick up the fight again after he almost gave up and reassured him whenever he doubted himself and their cause.

She brought in the Knights of Vale when Jon nearly lost the Battle of Bastards, which turned the battle into the Starks’ favour in an instance. 

Their joint effort brought the Starks to the greatest and most meaningful victory after years of being betrayed, murdered, continuously beaten down, and being robbed of everything that belongs to their family. The Boltons was punished accordingly for their many crimes: betraying and murdering Robb, Catelyn & Talisa, burning down Winterfell, oppressing the North and abusing Sansa.

Sitting under the weirwood tree at the heart of Winterfell, Sansa reflected on her path. She admitted that she was wrong as a child to dream of another life down South, not noticing that she had already got a treasure at home. 

I came here every day when I was a girl. I prayed to be somewhere else. Back then I only thought about what I wanted, never about what I had. I was a stupid girl. (Sansa to Littlefinger, 6x10)

Gif thecrowandthelittlebird

After all she had been through, Sansa realized that she didn’t have to go anywhere else to find happiness. Happiness was right here, always, in Winterfell. Although half of her family were gone and her home had been so much destroyed throughout the years, they were still the best thing she ever had. She found her passion and responsibility to protect whoever and whatever piece of home that remained. In season 7, as the Lady of Winterfell, Sansa ruled the North in Jon’s absence. She’s been effectively preparing Winterfell and the North for the coming storms, at the same time, getting rid of Littlefinger, the man who orchestrated her family’s downfall. As she declared before executing Littlefinger, she didn’t want to execute him but she would do everything necessary to defend those matter most to her. 

It’s not what I want. It’s what honor demands. That I defend my family from those who would harm us. That I defend the North from those who would betray us. (Sansa to Littlefinger, 7x07)

Sansa’s homecoming journey is about self-empowerment. She has grown from from a naive little girl who dreams to live like a lady in a song to strong, intelligent and independent women who can decide her own destiny and influence others. She has evolved from a pawn to a decisive player in the game. Her diplomatic and political competency could help to cement the political standings of the Starks in Westeros. Learning from Robb’s mistakes, Sansa understood the importance of listening to people’s concerns and find ways to make everyone work together instead of purely using laws, order and punishment to make them submit. 

Besides, Sansa has demonstrated that she possesses excellent administrative skills which are very helpful to effectively run the kingdom. Arya herself admitted she would never as good a lady as Sansa (7x07). It’s now time for Sansa to step up and become a leader in her own right. Perhaps, among the Starklings, Sansa is now the one who is most sure of herself and what she wants: “peace and quiet”; Jon, Arya and Bran all back to her; safety for her family and her people. And perhaps in season 8, she would also realize that the dream of having a happy family of her own that mirrors her parents’ is not just a stupid dream after all. It’s real and it’s something worth fighting for.

Sansa really comes into her own this season. She knows what she wants. She knows what she stands for. She knows who she wants to be around, and she faces threats to that this season. (Sophie Turner on Sansa in season 8, interview with Vulture)

She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge. It’s the first time you ever see her like that, and it’s so amazing to see her like that – kind of owning her destiny. (Sophie Turner on Sansa in season 8, interview with Digital Spy)

Jon

Among the Starklings, Jon has the most problems with identity issues due to his status as a bastard. Back in season 1, Jon was eager to leave home to become a brother of the Night’s Watch like his Uncle Benjen, whom he admired. Before he left, his “father” reminded him that manning the Wall is a Starks’ duty for thousands of years and that he had a Stark blood despite not bearing the Stark name.

There’s great honor serving in the Night’s Watch. The Starks have manned the Wall for thousands of years. And you are a Stark. You might not have my name, but you have my blood. (Ned to Jon, 1x02) 

Being a “bastard”, Jon wanted to find ways to prove himself to his father. He might have chosen the Night’s Watch, a duty that the Starks have borne for thousands of years, and aspired to become a ranger like Uncle Benjen to make his father proud. He longed for the same attention his father granted Robb. 

I was jealous of Robb my whole life. The way my Father looked at him. I wanted that. (Jon to Sam, 4x01)

Jon’s deepest fear is rejection, that he is not a Stark. In his nightmares, he saw himself running through in an empty Winterfell to the crypts.

And then I find myself in front of the door to the crypts. It’s black inside, and I can see the steps spiraling down. Somehow I know I have to go down there, but I don’t want to. I’m afraid of what might be waiting for me. The old Kings of Winter are down there, sitting on their thrones with stone wolves at their feet and iron swords across their laps, but it’s not them I’m afraid of. I scream that I’m not a Stark, that this isn’t my place, but it’s no good, I have to go anyway, do I start down, feeling the walls as I descend, with no torch to light the way. (Jon IV, A Game of Thrones)

Being recognized as a Stark is Jon’s biggest passion. He loves and adores Ned and in his wildest dream, he dreamed that his father would place Ice in his hand. 

When Jon had been Bran’s age, he had dreamed of doing great deeds, as boys always did. The details of his feats changed with every dreaming, but quite often he imagined saving his father’s life. Afterward, Lord Eddard would declare that Jon had proved himself a true Stark, and place Ice in his hand. Even then he had known it was only a child’s folly; no bastard could ever hope to wield a father’s sword. (Jon VIII, A Game of Thrones)

Even after Lord Mormont gave him Long Claw, an honor that no bastard could dare dream of, here was what Jon thought. 

He (Lord Mormont) is not my father. The thought leapt unbidden to Jon’s mind. Lord Eddard Stark is my father. I will not forget him, no matter how many swords they give me. (Jon VIII, A Game of Thrones)

Upon learning about Ned’s death, Jon decided to leave the Night’s Watch to join Robb avenging their father. He hoped that Robb would take him in and he would have chance fight those who murdered his father on the battlefield.

Jon was not afraid of death, but he did not want to die like that, trussed and bound and beheaded like a common brigand. If he must perish, let it be with a sword in his hand, fighting his father’s killers. He was no true Stark, had never been one … but he could die like one. Let them say that Eddard Stark had fathered four sons, not three. (Jon IX, A Game of Thrones) 

His comrades intercepted and convinced him to stay. The next day, Lord Commander Mormont told Jon that fighting the White Walkers to protect the living is more important than the wars of the lords. Jon then swore to Mormont that he would not attempt to desert again and joined the mission beyond the Wall. Since then, the Night’s Watch became his family, Castle Black became his home and “guarding the realm of men” is his sole mission. Even when he was living among the wildings (as a spy) and falling in love with Yigritte, Jon never forgot his Night’s Watch vow as “the sword in the darkness” and “the shield that guards the realm of men”.

After coming back from beyond the Wall and defeating the wildings’ attack, Jon received an offer from Stannis to legitimize him and make him Lord of Winterfell if he bent the knee to Stannis and helped him take Winterfell from the Boltons. The prospects of becoming Jon Stark, Lord of Winterfell excited him as he confessed to Sam.

It’s the first thing I ever remember wanting. I daydreamed that my father would ask the king. Just like that I would never be the Bastard of Winterfell again. (Jon to Sam, 5x02)    

In the book, he even thought of what he would do when he is Lord of Winterfell, his father’s heir. (It is not revealed in the show, but I don’t think that book!Jon and show!Jon would have different opinions in this regard.)

Winterfell, he thought. Theon left it burned and broken, but I could restore it. Surely his father would have wanted that, and Robb as well. They would never have wanted the castle left in ruins.  (Jon XII, A Storm of Swords)

However, Jon still declined Stannis’ offer and chose to uphold his Night’s Watch’s vow and only left the Night’s Watch after being murdered by his “brothers”. Believing that his Stark family was all dead and losing faith in his new family (the Night’s Watch), Jon decided to flee South and find some warmth. But Sansa arrived at the Wall right at that moment. After years apart, the Starks finally started to get back together with a very emotional reunion.

Gif:  daenerys-stormborn

The two people who couldn’t wait to leave Winterfell from the beginning to pursue their fantasies admitted to each other that they should never have left home in the first place (6x04).

Jon: We never should have left Winterfell.

Sansa: Don’t you wish we could go back to the day we left? I want to scream at myself, "Don’t go, you idiot.”

Jon: How can we know?

He was then convinced by Sansa to shift his commitment back to his family and fight for their home together. 

From that moment, they were no longer the lone wolves. A pack has been formed, starting with the White Wolf and the Red Wolf. 

It is notable that the moment Jon decided to leave the Night’s Watch, he started to wear the Stark armor, similar to the ones his “father” and “brother” used to wear.

The more Jon embraced his Stark root, the more he modeled himself after Ned.

From the hairstyle…

To the fur cloak…

I made this for you. I made it like the one Father used to wear. As near as I can remember. (Sansa to Jon, 6x05)

Sansa did a great job in boosting Jon’s confidence. She constantly reminded him that he was every bit of their Father. 

You are the son of the last true Warden of the North. Northern families are loyal. They’ll fight for you if you ask. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

They even styled themselves after their deceased Father and Mother to present the Starks as an unit to all the Northern houses. 

While riding across the North with his “sister” to rally an army against the Boltons, Jon regained pride and confidence in his House and himself, thanks to Sansa’s efforts.      

Robb is gone, but House Stark is not. (Jon to Lyanna Mormont, 6x07)    

Defeating Ramsay in the Battle of Bastards, Jon and Sansa retook their home but the victory was not without costs. Being used as a bait to lure Jon into a trap, Rickon died with an arrow to the heart by Ramsay, just seconds before Jon could reach him. It was a tragic end for Rickon, and another trauma for both Jon and Sansa: Another lone wolf died when he was just a few steps away to finally reaching his pack.

After retaking Winterfell, Jon is hailed by the Northern lords as the new King in the North with Sansa by his side, echoing the scene when Robb was proclaimed King with Catelyn by his side in season 1, making the Stark homecoming campaign full circle. Never before in his life was Jon so sure of his Stark-ness when his wolf blood was firmly acknowledged.

First by Sansa.

Then in public, when he was recognized as the successor of Ned Stark and Robb Stark. 

Lyanna Mormont: House Mormont remembers. The North remembers. We know no king but the King in the North whose name is Stark. I don’t care if he’s a bastard. Ned Stark’s blood runs through his veins. He’s my king from this day until his last day.

Lord Manderly: My son died for Robb Stark, the Young Wolf. I didn’t think we’d find another king in my lifetime. I didn’t commit my men to your cause ‘cause I didn’t want more Manderlys dying for nothing. But I was wrong. Jon Snow avenged the Red Wedding. He is the White Wolf. The King in the North. (6x10)

Gif:  thenightkingcometh

All the recognition and appreciation he got made Jon’s pride as Ned Stark’s son and his self-confidence grow. He talks like Ned, quoting his father proudly in public. (Jon has a habit of quoting his “father”, showing how much influence Ned has on him.)

The free folk, the northerners, and the Knights of the Vale fought bravely, fought together, and we won. My father used to say we find our true friends on the battlefield. (Jon to the Northern lords, 6x10)

My father always said “The man who passes the sentence should swing the sword.” and I have tried to live by those words. (Jon to the Northern lords, 7x01)

And he even acts like Ned. 

As the King in the North and the big brother of his family, Jon bears the responsibility to ensure their survival when the Long Night comes. In season 7, he was away from home again on a mission to persuade Dany to join the North in the Great War against the Army of Dead. Before he left, he declared his determination. 

You all crowned me your King. I never wanted it. I never asked for it. But I accepted it because the North is my home. It’s part of me and I’ll never stop fighting for it, no matter the odds.” (Jon to the Northern lords, 7x02)    

It was not an easy diplomatic mission. Jon was kept as a guest-prisoner on Dragonstone and Dany repeatedly demanded him to bend the knee and bring the North under her rule in exchange for the help. Jon, desperate to return home with the much needed weapons (Dany’s dragons) and army to defend his people (and the realm), faced a difficult choice: to kneel or not to kneel. Deep down, he knows where his loyalty lies.

I serve the North. (Jon to Beric, 7x06)

To help Dany secure the truce with Cersei (so that she would march North to help fight against the Dead Army), Jon led a wight hunt mission that turned out to be a disaster in the end. He was then saved by his long lost Uncle Benjen who then sacrificed himself to help Jon flee from the Dead on the horseback.

Gif:  lovableamy

Seeing his beloved uncle being brought down by hundreds of wights, Jon knew if he couldn’t secure the alliance with Daenerys before the Dead Army passes the Wall, Bran, Arya and Sansa, the only family members he has left and everyone else he cares for will die. Jon would do everything now, even sacrificing his honor to save those he loves from such fate. His conversation with Theon after the dragonpit meeting gave a hint that he could be not truthful about “bending the knee” (7x07).

Theon: What you did in King’s Landing, what you said you could’ve lied to Cersei about bending the knee to Daenerys. You risked everything to tell an enemy the truth.

Jon: We went down there to make peace. And it seems to me we need to be honest with each other if we’re going to fight together.

Theon: You’ve always known what was right. Even when we were all young and stupid, you always knew. Every step you take it’s always the right step.

Jon: It’s not. It may seem that way from the outside, but I promise you, it’s not true. I’ve done plenty of things that I regret.

Jon’s homecoming journey is about duty as a protector of the realm (and his family), loyalty, self-realization and the quest for identity, love and acceptance. In season 8, when it is revealed to him that he is actually the Targaryen heir, Jon will have to choose the heritage he would embrace. For a man who’s spent all his life on a Starks’ duty (guarding the Wall to defend the living) and live by Starks’ principles (inspired by his father-uncle Ned and his uncle Benjen), it’s hard to believe that he will suddenly abandon the Starks to embrace the Targaryen’s “fire and blood” philosophy or to choose Dragonstone/ King’s Landing over Winterfell.

This moment under the heart tree in Winterfell could be a moment of reflection for Jon, when he finally chooses who are his real family, where his heart belongs,  whose legacy he would carry on, and who he fights for regardless of his lineage.

But I believe, we already have the answer. 

Beric: We’re soldiers. We have to know what we’re fighting for. I’m not fighting so some man or woman I barely know can sit in a throne made of swords. […] You and I won’t find much joy while we’re here. But we can keep up the life. We can defend those who can’t defend themselves.

Jon: I am the shield that guards the realm of men.

Beric: Maybe we don’t need to understand anymore than that. Maybe that’s enough. (6x06)

Jon would never fight for someone to sit on the Throne. His fight is to defend the people, his fight is for a day when he could rebuild his Home.

Winterfell, he thought. Theon left it burned and broken, but I could restore it. (Jon XII, A Storm of Swords)

Jon, Sansa, Arya and Bran have been through long and painful roads to be home together again. Their journeys are for them to embrace their Stark identity, overcome loss and hardships, and gain strengths to protect and rebuild their home and the North (and perhaps, the realm). What set their homecoming journeys apart from other major characters is, the Starklings have very strong sense of home and togetherness, and their paths lead them back to each other. Their shared responsibility is to “defend those who can’t defend themselves”, to fight for home, and for the living. They now have their own pack to rely on.

But being home is difficult, being able to hold it is even harder. The biggest battles are still ahead. Season 8 would be no less challenging and terrifying for them. Would they be able to put everything they’ve learned to practice to defend their home and their people? That is the topic for the next post. But for now, let’s celebrate the fact that the Stark kids are finally back to where they belong.

Everything you did brought you where you are now. Where you belong. Home.  (Bran in S8 trailer)
body_abstract:
Part 1: Theon & Jorah

Part 2: Jaime & Tyrion

Part 3.1: Robb- the lone wolf

In the previous part, we have discussed how Robb lost Winterfell and the North when he drove South for the war and how his choice of Vengeance over Home led him to his own demise. His decision to attack Casterly Rock instead of  reclaiming the North was the final nail in the coffin. Robb’s last war plan, which was a divergence from the books, was a conscious choice from the show writers to emphasize how Robb’s choice was different from that of his siblings. And I believe the consequences would be different. Robb chose the path of a lonewolf and he died. The surviving Stark kids would not repeat the mistakes of their brother. They would choose Home (and each other) over everything else. The strength of the pack will help them survive the Long Night and the threats from other enemies.

Throughout the length of the series, the kids were driven away from home, separated, constantly endangered, abused and even murdered. 

Each of them suffered traumatic experiences, witnessing their loved ones die horribly before their very eyes. However, despite being forced to abandon their identity, they never stopped thinking of home and their family. Winterfell (and the North) holds a sacred place in their heart, the place of childhood memory, love and hope. No other characters in the series have memories of home as vivid as the Starklings. Home is where they drew their strengths from.

“Winterfell is our home. It’s ours, and Arya’s, and Bran’s and Rickon’s, wherever they are. It belongs to our family. We have to fight for it.” (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

Home is the place where their paths finally converge. It was a promise from the beginning.

“Different roads sometimes lead to the same castle.” 

(Jon to Arya, Jon II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  makebeliever

Coming home to know who they are and who to fight for

In this part, we will have a brief look on the homecoming journeys of the Starklings and elaborate how their arcs mean for their future development and the restoration of House Stark. I will quote some texts from the books (which have been adapted on screen or do not contradict with what introduced to us about the characters by the show) to have a better of understanding about the inner thoughts and motivations of the characters.

Part 1: Theon & Jorah

Part 2: Jaime & Tyrion

Part 3.1: Robb- the lone wolf

In the previous part, we have discussed how Robb lost Winterfell and the North when he drove South for the war and how his choice of Vengeance over Home led him to his own demise. His decision to attack Casterly Rock instead of  reclaiming the North was the final nail in the coffin. Home is the place where their paths finally converge. It was a promise from the beginning.

“Different roads sometimes lead to the same castle.” 

(Jon to Arya, Jon II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  makebeliever

Coming home to know who they are and who to fight for

In this part, we will have a brief look on the homecoming journeys of the Starklings and elaborate how their arcs mean for their future development and the restoration of House Stark. I will quote some texts from the books (which have been adapted on screen or do not contradict with what introduced to us about the characters by the show) to have a better of understanding about the inner thoughts and motivations of the characters.

[[MORE]]

Bran

“Winterfell had been the only home he had ever known.” (Bran II, A Game of Thrones)

Among the Starklings, perhaps Bran is the most knowledgeable of the castle’s architecture and its stories, and the topography of  the surrounding area. He is the one who knows every little corner of Winterfell, even the most secretive part of it. As the younger son, Bran didn’t expect to inherit the ancestral home. His role is to become Robb’s bannerman. But he had his own way to become lord of the castle. As he frequently climbed to Winterfell’s rooftop, where he claimed his “second home”, he saw the life of the castle, everyone, and everything.

Bran could perch for hours among the shapeless, rain-worn gargoyles that brooded over the First Keep, watching it all: the men drilling with wood and steel in the yard, the cooks tending their vegetables in the glass garden, restless dogs running back and forth in the kennels, the silence of the godswood, the girls gossiping beside the washing well. It made him feel like he was the lord of the castle, in a way even Robb would never know. (Bran II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

Even the crypts do not frighten Bran. He feels like he is a part of it.

Their footsteps echoed through the cavernous crypts. The shadows behind them swallowed his father as the shadows ahead retreated to unveil other statues; no mere lords, these, but the old Kings in the North. On their brows they wore stone crowns. […] Their faces were stern and strong, and some of them had done terrible things, but they were Starks everyone, and Bran knew all their tales. He had never feared the crypts; they were part of his home and who he was, and he had always known that one day he would lie here too. (Bran VII, A Clash of Kings)

Bran’s happy childhood didn’t last long. His life changed upside down after he was shoved from the tower by Jaime and lost his mobility. However, the worst was yet to come. Waking up from his coma, Bran was disappointed that his mother had left him, although she left to investigate the cause of his fall and to demand justice for him. Maester Luwin was surprised and couldn’t answer the seemingly childlike question from Bran.

Luwin: Your mother had to leave Winterfell to protect the family.

Bran: How can she protect the family if she’s not with her family?

What happened after proved that Bran was actually reasonable. One cannot protect the family while he/she is not with the family. Robb left for war and Bran was assumed Lord of Winterfell in his stead. That was a huge responsibility for a cripple 10-year-old child. With the help from Maester Luwin, Bran took care of Winterfell and its people, showing great potentials to become a good lord. 

Still, defending the whole North and Winterfell while the best Northern soldiers were going South with Robb was too much of a responsibility for a child. Winterfell was sacked after a surprise attack from ironbonn led by Theon. Bran experienced the first horrors in his life seeing Ser Rodrick beheaded, his house burnt and Master Luwin killed. 

In his last words, Maester Luwin reminded Bran that there was still hope under the ruins, as long as he lived.

Bran: They burnt everything. 

Luwin: Not everything. Not you. (2x10)

The castle gave Bran strength to carry on. As he fled North, he turned to have a last look of “the castle that had been his life”.

The stone is strong, Bran told himself, the roots of the trees go deep, and under the ground the Kings of Winter sit their thrones. So long as those remained, Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken. Like me, he thought, I’m not dead either. (Bran VII, A Clash of Kings)

Following the call from the Bloodraven, Bran and his companion arrived in a cave under a heart tree beyond the Wall. While he was training in the cave, Bran was frequently brought back to Winterfell in the visions and he didn’t want to leave. Because staying in the visions was the only way he could be home.

When Bloodraven warned him if he stayed in the visions for too long, he will be drowned, he responded with despair.

I wasn’t drowning. I was Home. (Bran to Bloodraven, 6x02)

Bran has been through a horrific journey. Be crippled by a knight he aspired to become when he grows up, betrayed and captured by a surrogate brother, witnessed Ser Rodrick and Maester Luwin killed, saw his home burnt, captured and tortured by the mutineers, witnessed the death of his mentors and companions, hunted by the dead beyond the Wall, learned in a short time to master the magical power he can hardly control. Now he’s back home but it’s not yet safe. The Dead is marching on them, and he bears the responsibility to face the Night King and save his home and humankind. As a child, Bran always dreamed to become a knight and was so devastated when he learned he could never walk again, meaning there was no chance to fulfilling his dream. But he might in the end be a knight in another way. 

Benjen to Bran: You must learn to control it before the Night King comes. One way or another, he will find his way to the world of men. And when he does, you will be there waiting for him. And you will be ready. (6x06)

Bran to Sansa: I need to learn to see better. When the Long Night comes again, I need to be ready. (7x03)

Bran’s journey home is for him to gain knowledge and wisdom about history and learn to apply such insights for the benefit of mankind. In season 7, Bran lost his sense of self. He claims to be the 3-Eyed-Raven now and only remembers how it was to be Bran Stark. Does he forget that he is Bran? Does he forget he is a Stark? For someone who knows and loves every inch of Winterfell, who knows all the story of the Starks before him, who endured so much pain and horror to be back home and defend it, just to lose himself and become emotionless would render the story totally bitter and quite meaningless.

It’s not like he’s not Bran anymore. It’s just the part of his head that is Bran is a much, much smaller part of his personality now. When he is with the Starks and his family, that part of him flares up. But really, he’s transcended that – he kind of exists beyond human beings and human issues and problems. He is time. (Isaac Hempstead Wright on Bran Stark in season 8) 

I’m very curious to see how Bran continues his journey. And if the speculation that the Night King was the ancestor of House Stark is true, perhaps in season 8, Bran would need to learn much more about his family’s history and secrets, and he would come to understand what it truly means to be a Stark of Winterfell. 

Arya

Arya left Winterfell for King’s Landing with Ned and Sansa since season 1 and ever since, her life has become a horror story.

After Ned was beheaded, Arya went into the hiding, travelled with the Night’s Watch’s recruits, became a captive at Harrenhal and then the Hound’s. Her hope of reuniting with her mother and her brother Robb was scattered when she finally arrived at the Red Wedding just in time to witness her family and the Stark soldiers being slaughtered and Robb’s headless body was mocked. 

Gif:  lovableamy

After wandering in the Riverlands and Eyrie with the Hound, Arya fled to Bravos to become an assassin. Revenge became her sole purpose in life. Citing the list of people she wanted to kill was her bedtime habit.

In order to become a Faceless Man, Arya was trained to give up who she was to become “no one”. However, at the back of her mind, Arya could never forget where she came from.

When you smell our candles burning, what does it make you think of, my child? Winterfell, she might have said. I smell Hodor laughing, and Jon and Robb battling in the yard, and Sansa singing about some stupid lady fair. I smell the crypts where the stone kings sit, I smell hot bread baking, I smell the godswood. I smell my wolf, I smell her fur, almost as if she were still beside me. (Arya II, A Feast for Crows)

As Jaqen requested, Arya had to give up her possession. She threw her old clothing and silver into the lagoon, but was unable to let go of Needle, the tiny piece of Home that still remained with her. She then chose to hide the sword under the rocks.

Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes. (Arya II, A Feast for Crows)

Even when Arya managed to defeat the Waif and was claimed by Jaqen to finally be “No one”, she refused and declared that she was always Arya Stark of Winterfell while pointing Needle at his chest.

A girl is Arya Stark of Winterfell. And I’m going Home. (Arya to Jaqen H’ghar, 6x08)

She then left the House of Black and White to come back to Westeros and continue her revenge mission by wiping out House Frey. 

Gif:  supercanaries

On her way to King’s Landing to finish her kill list (Cersei), Arya was informed that Jon had taken back Winterfell and became King in the North. She decided to abandon the mission and go home instead, prioritizing her family over vengeance. The moment Arya changed her direction and rode back to Winterfell was when she stopped being a lone wolf. She finally had a pack to join. 

Nymeria, it’s me. Arya. I’m heading North, girl. Back to Wintefell. I’m finally going Home. Come with me. (Arya to Nymeria, 7x02)

Arya’s homecoming journey revolves much around brutality, death, revenge and justice. The degree of ruthlessness and brutality she inflicted on her enemies is quite alarming. Luckily, the bright spot is, she never let hatred and rage took over her to the point that she would kill innocents. She refused to complete her assignment of killing Lady Crane (note that the actress actually played Cersei, her number one enemey), knowing fully well that the failed mission would risk her life. Later on, aware of the Frey women’s innocence in the Red Wedding, she didn’t let them drink the poisoned wine either.

Among the Stark kids, Arya has the highest risk of following Robb’s footsteps since revenge has become her primary motivation for a considerable period of time. And as far as we know, blind vengeance only leads to self-destruction. And I hope that would not be the path for Arya. Her childhood was ruined by all the misfortunes happened to her family, forcing her to become a cold-blooded assassin. Winterfell and all the good memories of her family were the only lights in Arya’s darkest days which prevent her from totally losing herself and the humanity that was left in her. Now she’s home with her siblings, would the love in her heart eventually outgrow the hatred that she embraced for years?

There’s this split with Arya between trying to be who she wants to be — getting back to back to that naiveté and innocence with her family — and her unfinished business. (Maisie Williams on Arya Stark in season 8, EW interview)

Another positive aspect of Arya’s journey that makes us hopeful is, while travelling across a war-torn Westeros, Arya lived among the common folks, befriended with them and suffered the same as they did, she comes to understand the ugliness of war, of the current oppressive social system and what the people really need. She develops a sense of empathy with the common people and is always ready to defend the weak. Her path also led her to an encounter with the Lannister soldiers when she realized the soldiers were just common folks dragged into someone else’s war. They are humans with all the concerns, and hopes and dreams, and families to care for, just like her. 

This is a parallel with Robb’s encounter with the Lannister child soldier who lost his leg in the Battle of Oxcross, allowing us to see wars from different view point. I believe with all her experiences living among the commoners, Arya will finally realize that wars and revenge would not be the solution for Westeros. Would that be interesting if the person who is driven by revenge is the one who learns to forgive and actively seek out a way to end war for the benefit of the common people? Would that be meaningful if the person who is trained to bring death, to serve the Many-Faced God will end up fighting to save lives?

Arya knows that she can never be as good a lady (aka a ruler) as Sansa and she still need to figure out what she can do.

I was never going to be as good as a lady as you. So I have to be something else. (Arya to Sansa, 7x07)

What does “something else” mean for Arya? A fighter, maybe. But she might also have a more important role to play in the political landscape of the North (and Westeros) afterwards.

Remember Robb’s conversation with Talisa about his father?

Gif:  iheartgot

He once told me that being a lord is like being a father, except you have thousands of children and you worry about all of them. The farmers plowing the fields are yours to protect. The charwomen scrubbing the floors, yours to protect. The soldiers you order into battle. (Robb to Talisa, 2x08)

Taking care of the common folks under their rule is a Stark tradition.

Since Arya is so much inspired by Ned, she will follow the example of her father when she comes back to Winterfell. 

Back at Winterfell, they had eaten in the Great Hall almost half the time. Her father used to say that a lord needed to eat with his men, if he hoped to keep them. “Know the men who follow you,” she heard him tell Robb once, “and let them know you. Don’t ask your men to die for a stranger.” At Winterfell, he always had an extra seat set at his own table, and everyday a different man would be asked to join him. […] Arya had loved nothing better than to sit at her father’s table and listen to them talk. (Arya II, A Game of Thrones) 

Sitting among the soldiers and commoners, talking with them, listening to their concerns and being the voice of the people, it’s not too far-fetch to picture Arya that way. The skills she learned as a Faceless Men trainee to play her part as someone else, “speak in their voices”, “live in their skin” could be transcended to serve people instead, if she could utilize such skills to empathize with people of various backgrounds. But first of all, let’s pray that she would find the strength to let go of vengeance and deploy her “expertise” for good. 

Sansa

Sansa began the series excited to leave home for King’s Landing to fulfill her dream of marrying a handsome young prince and becoming queen someday. Her dream soon turned into a nightmare when Ned was executed.

She was then used a pawn passed around by the powerful players in the game, including the Lannisters, the Tyrells, Littlefinger, the Boltons. She went through a series of mistreat and abuses both mentally and physically under several captors who murdered her family; and was forced into marriage for her claim of the North several times against her will. Sansa had little agency over her situation, she had to pretend to survive, but in her mind, she was free. She is still a Stark, through and through; and her heart belongs to Winterfell.

I’m a Stark. I’ll always be a Stark. (Sansa to Lyanna Mormont when questioned if she is a Bolton or a Lannister due to her (forced) marriages, 6x07)

The scene where Sansa built the snow castle in the Eyrie is a masterpiece, both in the book and the show.

The snow fell and the castle rose. Two walls ankle-high, the inner taller than the outer. Towers and turrets, keeps and stairs, a round kitchen, a square armory, the stables along the inside of the west wall. It was only a castle when she began, but before very long Sansa knew it was Winterfell. She found twigs and fallen branches beneath the snow and broke off the ends to make the trees for the godswood. For the gravestones in the lichyard she used bits of bark. Soon her gloves and her boots were crusty white, her hands were tingling, and her feet were soaked and cold, but she did not care. The castle was all that mattered. Some things were hard to remember, but most came back to her easily, as if she had been there only yesterday. The Library Tower, with the steep stonework stair twisting about its exterior. The gatehouse, two huge bulwarks, the arched gate between them, crenellations all along the top… (Sansa VII, A Storm of Swords)

It is amazing about the level of details that Sansa remembered about Winterfell and how she crafted it from the snow. Among the Starklings, perhaps Sansa and Bran are those who know so much details of the castle architecture, foreshadowing they will be the ones who rebuild the structure after the war.

Like her siblings, Sansa also drew her strengths from Winterfell in her darkest days.

She wondered where this courage had come from, to speak to him (Littlefinger) so frankly. From Winterfell, she thought. I am stronger within the walls of Winterfell. (Sansa VII, A Storm of Swords)

Even Ramsay’s abuse couldn’t break Sansa then. After her escape, Sansa was more determined than ever to take back her home from the Boltons.

There’s only one place we can go. Home. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

If we don’t take back the North, we’ll never be safe. I want you to help me, but I’ll do it myself if I have to. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

Sansa played a pivotal role in regaining Winterfell for the Starks. With her wits, she provoked Ramsay about the fragility of his position due to his bastard status, indirectly causing the death of Roose Bolton, thus eliminating the man who betrayed Robb.

Her strong determination motivated Jon to pick up the fight again after he almost gave up and reassured him whenever he doubted himself and their cause.

She brought in the Knights of Vale when Jon nearly lost the Battle of Bastards, which turned the battle into the Starks’ favour in an instance. 

Their joint effort brought the Starks to the greatest and most meaningful victory after years of being betrayed, murdered, continuously beaten down, and being robbed of everything that belongs to their family. The Boltons was punished accordingly for their many crimes: betraying and murdering Robb, Catelyn & Talisa, burning down Winterfell, oppressing the North and abusing Sansa.

Sitting under the weirwood tree at the heart of Winterfell, Sansa reflected on her path. She admitted that she was wrong as a child to dream of another life down South, not noticing that she had already got a treasure at home. 

I came here every day when I was a girl. I prayed to be somewhere else. Back then I only thought about what I wanted, never about what I had. I was a stupid girl. (Sansa to Littlefinger, 6x10)

Gif thecrowandthelittlebird

After all she had been through, Sansa realized that she didn’t have to go anywhere else to find happiness. Happiness was right here, always, in Winterfell. Although half of her family were gone and her home had been so much destroyed throughout the years, they were still the best thing she ever had. She found her passion and responsibility to protect whoever and whatever piece of home that remained. In season 7, as the Lady of Winterfell, Sansa ruled the North in Jon’s absence. She’s been effectively preparing Winterfell and the North for the coming storms, at the same time, getting rid of Littlefinger, the man who orchestrated her family’s downfall. As she declared before executing Littlefinger, she didn’t want to execute him but she would do everything necessary to defend those matter most to her. 

It’s not what I want. It’s what honor demands. That I defend my family from those who would harm us. That I defend the North from those who would betray us. (Sansa to Littlefinger, 7x07)

Sansa’s homecoming journey is about self-empowerment. She has grown from from a naive little girl who dreams to live like a lady in a song to strong, intelligent and independent women who can decide her own destiny and influence others. She has evolved from a pawn to a decisive player in the game. Her diplomatic and political competency could help to cement the political standings of the Starks in Westeros. Learning from Robb’s mistakes, Sansa understood the importance of listening to people’s concerns and find ways to make everyone work together instead of purely using laws, order and punishment to make them submit. 

Besides, Sansa has demonstrated that she possesses excellent administrative skills which are very helpful to effectively run the kingdom. Arya herself admitted she would never as good a lady as Sansa (7x07). It’s now time for Sansa to step up and become a leader in her own right. Perhaps, among the Starklings, Sansa is now the one who is most sure of herself and what she wants: “peace and quiet”; Jon, Arya and Bran all back to her; safety for her family and her people. And perhaps in season 8, she would also realize that the dream of having a happy family of her own that mirrors her parents’ is not just a stupid dream after all. It’s real and it’s something worth fighting for.

Sansa really comes into her own this season. She knows what she wants. She knows what she stands for. She knows who she wants to be around, and she faces threats to that this season. (Sophie Turner on Sansa in season 8, interview with Vulture)

She’s a real, true leader of Winterfell now. And that’s where we first see her – as a very protective, empowered lady in charge. It’s the first time you ever see her like that, and it’s so amazing to see her like that – kind of owning her destiny. (Sophie Turner on Sansa in season 8, interview with Digital Spy)

Jon

Among the Starklings, Jon has the most problems with identity issues due to his status as a bastard. Back in season 1, Jon was eager to leave home to become a brother of the Night’s Watch like his Uncle Benjen, whom he admired. Before he left, his “father” reminded him that manning the Wall is a Starks’ duty for thousands of years and that he had a Stark blood despite not bearing the Stark name.

There’s great honor serving in the Night’s Watch. The Starks have manned the Wall for thousands of years. And you are a Stark. You might not have my name, but you have my blood. (Ned to Jon, 1x02) 

Being a “bastard”, Jon wanted to find ways to prove himself to his father. He might have chosen the Night’s Watch, a duty that the Starks have borne for thousands of years, and aspired to become a ranger like Uncle Benjen to make his father proud. He longed for the same attention his father granted Robb. 

I was jealous of Robb my whole life. The way my Father looked at him. I wanted that. (Jon to Sam, 4x01)

Jon’s deepest fear is rejection, that he is not a Stark. In his nightmares, he saw himself running through in an empty Winterfell to the crypts.

And then I find myself in front of the door to the crypts. It’s black inside, and I can see the steps spiraling down. Somehow I know I have to go down there, but I don’t want to. I’m afraid of what might be waiting for me. The old Kings of Winter are down there, sitting on their thrones with stone wolves at their feet and iron swords across their laps, but it’s not them I’m afraid of. I scream that I’m not a Stark, that this isn’t my place, but it’s no good, I have to go anyway, do I start down, feeling the walls as I descend, with no torch to light the way. (Jon IV, A Game of Thrones)

Being recognized as a Stark is Jon’s biggest passion. He loves and adores Ned and in his wildest dream, he dreamed that his father would place Ice in his hand. 

When Jon had been Bran’s age, he had dreamed of doing great deeds, as boys always did. The details of his feats changed with every dreaming, but quite often he imagined saving his father’s life. Afterward, Lord Eddard would declare that Jon had proved himself a true Stark, and place Ice in his hand. Even then he had known it was only a child’s folly; no bastard could ever hope to wield a father’s sword. (Jon VIII, A Game of Thrones)

Even after Lord Mormont gave him Long Claw, an honor that no bastard could dare dream of, here was what Jon thought. 

He (Lord Mormont) is not my father. The thought leapt unbidden to Jon’s mind. Lord Eddard Stark is my father. I will not forget him, no matter how many swords they give me. (Jon VIII, A Game of Thrones)

Upon learning about Ned’s death, Jon decided to leave the Night’s Watch to join Robb avenging their father. He hoped that Robb would take him in and he would have chance fight those who murdered his father on the battlefield.

Jon was not afraid of death, but he did not want to die like that, trussed and bound and beheaded like a common brigand. If he must perish, let it be with a sword in his hand, fighting his father’s killers. He was no true Stark, had never been one … but he could die like one. Let them say that Eddard Stark had fathered four sons, not three. (Jon IX, A Game of Thrones) 

His comrades intercepted and convinced him to stay. The next day, Lord Commander Mormont told Jon that fighting the White Walkers to protect the living is more important than the wars of the lords. Jon then swore to Mormont that he would not attempt to desert again and joined the mission beyond the Wall. Since then, the Night’s Watch became his family, Castle Black became his home and “guarding the realm of men” is his sole mission. Even when he was living among the wildings (as a spy) and falling in love with Yigritte, Jon never forgot his Night’s Watch vow as “the sword in the darkness” and “the shield that guards the realm of men”.

After coming back from beyond the Wall and defeating the wildings’ attack, Jon received an offer from Stannis to legitimize him and make him Lord of Winterfell if he bent the knee to Stannis and helped him take Winterfell from the Boltons. The prospects of becoming Jon Stark, Lord of Winterfell excited him as he confessed to Sam.

It’s the first thing I ever remember wanting. I daydreamed that my father would ask the king. Just like that I would never be the Bastard of Winterfell again. (Jon to Sam, 5x02)    

In the book, he even thought of what he would do when he is Lord of Winterfell, his father’s heir. (It is not revealed in the show, but I don’t think that book!Jon and show!Jon would have different opinions in this regard.)

Winterfell, he thought. Theon left it burned and broken, but I could restore it. Surely his father would have wanted that, and Robb as well. They would never have wanted the castle left in ruins.  (Jon XII, A Storm of Swords)

However, Jon still declined Stannis’ offer and chose to uphold his Night’s Watch’s vow and only left the Night’s Watch after being murdered by his “brothers”. Believing that his Stark family was all dead and losing faith in his new family (the Night’s Watch), Jon decided to flee South and find some warmth. But Sansa arrived at the Wall right at that moment. After years apart, the Starks finally started to get back together with a very emotional reunion.

Gif:  daenerys-stormborn

The two people who couldn’t wait to leave Winterfell from the beginning to pursue their fantasies admitted to each other that they should never have left home in the first place (6x04).

Jon: We never should have left Winterfell.

Sansa: Don’t you wish we could go back to the day we left? I want to scream at myself, "Don’t go, you idiot.”

Jon: How can we know?

He was then convinced by Sansa to shift his commitment back to his family and fight for their home together. 

From that moment, they were no longer the lone wolves. A pack has been formed, starting with the White Wolf and the Red Wolf. 

It is notable that the moment Jon decided to leave the Night’s Watch, he started to wear the Stark armor, similar to the ones his “father” and “brother” used to wear.

The more Jon embraced his Stark root, the more he modeled himself after Ned.

From the hairstyle…

To the fur cloak…

I made this for you. I made it like the one Father used to wear. As near as I can remember. (Sansa to Jon, 6x05)

Sansa did a great job in boosting Jon’s confidence. She constantly reminded him that he was every bit of their Father. 

You are the son of the last true Warden of the North. Northern families are loyal. They’ll fight for you if you ask. (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

They even styled themselves after their deceased Father and Mother to present the Starks as an unit to all the Northern houses. 

While riding across the North with his “sister” to rally an army against the Boltons, Jon regained pride and confidence in his House and himself, thanks to Sansa’s efforts.      

Robb is gone, but House Stark is not. (Jon to Lyanna Mormont, 6x07)    

Defeating Ramsay in the Battle of Bastards, Jon and Sansa retook their home but the victory was not without costs. Being used as a bait to lure Jon into a trap, Rickon died with an arrow to the heart by Ramsay, just seconds before Jon could reach him. It was a tragic end for Rickon, and another trauma for both Jon and Sansa: Another lone wolf died when he was just a few steps away to finally reaching his pack.

After retaking Winterfell, Jon is hailed by the Northern lords as the new King in the North with Sansa by his side, echoing the scene when Robb was proclaimed King with Catelyn by his side in season 1, making the Stark homecoming campaign full circle. Never before in his life was Jon so sure of his Stark-ness when his wolf blood was firmly acknowledged.

First by Sansa.

Then in public, when he was recognized as the successor of Ned Stark and Robb Stark. 

Lyanna Mormont: House Mormont remembers. The North remembers. We know no king but the King in the North whose name is Stark. I don’t care if he’s a bastard. Ned Stark’s blood runs through his veins. He’s my king from this day until his last day.

Lord Manderly: My son died for Robb Stark, the Young Wolf. I didn’t think we’d find another king in my lifetime. I didn’t commit my men to your cause ‘cause I didn’t want more Manderlys dying for nothing. But I was wrong. Jon Snow avenged the Red Wedding. He is the White Wolf. The King in the North. (6x10)

Gif:  thenightkingcometh

All the recognition and appreciation he got made Jon’s pride as Ned Stark’s son and his self-confidence grow. He talks like Ned, quoting his father proudly in public. (Jon has a habit of quoting his “father”, showing how much influence Ned has on him.)

The free folk, the northerners, and the Knights of the Vale fought bravely, fought together, and we won. My father used to say we find our true friends on the battlefield. (Jon to the Northern lords, 6x10)

My father always said “The man who passes the sentence should swing the sword.” and I have tried to live by those words. (Jon to the Northern lords, 7x01)

And he even acts like Ned. 

As the King in the North and the big brother of his family, Jon bears the responsibility to ensure their survival when the Long Night comes. In season 7, he was away from home again on a mission to persuade Dany to join the North in the Great War against the Army of Dead. Before he left, he declared his determination. 

You all crowned me your King. I never wanted it. I never asked for it. But I accepted it because the North is my home. It’s part of me and I’ll never stop fighting for it, no matter the odds.” (Jon to the Northern lords, 7x02)    

It was not an easy diplomatic mission. Jon was kept as a guest-prisoner on Dragonstone and Dany repeatedly demanded him to bend the knee and bring the North under her rule in exchange for the help. Jon, desperate to return home with the much needed weapons (Dany’s dragons) and army to defend his people (and the realm), faced a difficult choice: to kneel or not to kneel. Deep down, he knows where his loyalty lies.

I serve the North. (Jon to Beric, 7x06)

To help Dany secure the truce with Cersei (so that she would march North to help fight against the Dead Army), Jon led a wight hunt mission that turned out to be a disaster in the end. He was then saved by his long lost Uncle Benjen who then sacrificed himself to help Jon flee from the Dead on the horseback.

Gif:  lovableamy

Seeing his beloved uncle being brought down by hundreds of wights, Jon knew if he couldn’t secure the alliance with Daenerys before the Dead Army passes the Wall, Bran, Arya and Sansa, the only family members he has left and everyone else he cares for will die. Jon would do everything now, even sacrificing his honor to save those he loves from such fate. His conversation with Theon after the dragonpit meeting gave a hint that he could be not truthful about “bending the knee” (7x07).

Theon: What you did in King’s Landing, what you said you could’ve lied to Cersei about bending the knee to Daenerys. You risked everything to tell an enemy the truth.

Jon: We went down there to make peace. And it seems to me we need to be honest with each other if we’re going to fight together.

Theon: You’ve always known what was right. Even when we were all young and stupid, you always knew. Every step you take it’s always the right step.

Jon: It’s not. It may seem that way from the outside, but I promise you, it’s not true. I’ve done plenty of things that I regret.

Jon’s homecoming journey is about duty as a protector of the realm (and his family), loyalty, self-realization and the quest for identity, love and acceptance. In season 8, when it is revealed to him that he is actually the Targaryen heir, Jon will have to choose the heritage he would embrace. For a man who’s spent all his life on a Starks’ duty (guarding the Wall to defend the living) and live by Starks’ principles (inspired by his father-uncle Ned and his uncle Benjen), it’s hard to believe that he will suddenly abandon the Starks to embrace the Targaryen’s “fire and blood” philosophy or to choose Dragonstone/ King’s Landing over Winterfell.

This moment under the heart tree in Winterfell could be a moment of reflection for Jon, when he finally chooses who are his real family, where his heart belongs,  whose legacy he would carry on, and who he fights for regardless of his lineage.

But I believe, we already have the answer. 

Beric: We’re soldiers. We have to know what we’re fighting for. I’m not fighting so some man or woman I barely know can sit in a throne made of swords. […] You and I won’t find much joy while we’re here. But we can keep up the life. We can defend those who can’t defend themselves.

Jon: I am the shield that guards the realm of men.

Beric: Maybe we don’t need to understand anymore than that. Maybe that’s enough. (6x06)

Jon would never fight for someone to sit on the Throne. His fight is to defend the people, his fight is for a day when he could rebuild his Home.

Winterfell, he thought. Theon left it burned and broken, but I could restore it. (Jon XII, A Storm of Swords)

Jon, Sansa, Arya and Bran have been through long and painful roads to be home together again. Their journeys are for them to embrace their Stark identity, overcome loss and hardships, and gain strengths to protect and rebuild their home and the North (and perhaps, the realm). What set their homecoming journeys apart from other major characters is, the Starklings have very strong sense of home and togetherness, and their paths lead them back to each other. Their shared responsibility is to “defend those who can’t defend themselves”, to fight for home, and for the living. They now have their own pack to rely on.

But being home is difficult, being able to hold it is even harder. The biggest battles are still ahead. Season 8 would be no less challenging and terrifying for them. Would they be able to put everything they’ve learned to practice to defend their home and their people? That is the topic for the next post. But for now, let’s celebrate the fact that the Stark kids are finally back to where they belong.

Everything you did brought you where you are now. Where you belong. Home.  (Bran in S8 trailer)

trail.content_raw:
Part 1: Theon & Jorah

Part 2: Jaime & Tyrion

Part 3.1: Robb- the lone wolf

In the previous part, we have discussed how Robb lost Winterfell and the North when he drove South for the war and how his choice of Vengeance over Home led him to his own demise. His decision to attack Casterly Rock instead of  reclaiming the North was the final nail in the coffin. Robb’s last war plan, which was a divergence from the books, was a conscious choice from the show writers to emphasize how Robb’s choice was different from that of his siblings. And I believe the consequences would be different. Robb chose the path of a lonewolf and he died. The surviving Stark kids would not repeat the mistakes of their brother. They would choose Home (and each other) over everything else. The strength of the pack will help them survive the Long Night and the threats from other enemies.

Throughout the length of the series, the kids were driven away from home, separated, constantly endangered, abused and even murdered. 

Each of them suffered traumatic experiences, witnessing their loved ones die horribly before their very eyes. However, despite being forced to abandon their identity, they never stopped thinking of home and their family. Winterfell (and the North) holds a sacred place in their heart, the place of childhood memory, love and hope. No other characters in the series have memories of home as vivid as the Starklings. Home is where they drew their strengths from.

“Winterfell is our home. It’s ours, and Arya’s, and Bran’s and Rickon’s, wherever they are. It belongs to our family. We have to fight for it.” (Sansa to Jon, 6x04)

Home is the place where their paths finally converge. It was a promise from the beginning.

“Different roads sometimes lead to the same castle.” 

(Jon to Arya, Jon II, A Game of Thrones)

Gif:  makebeliever

Coming home to know who they are and who to fight for
